16.1. Let G be a finite non-abelian group, and Z(G) its centre. One can associate a graph ΓG with G as follows: take G\Z(G) as vertices of ΓG and join two vertices x and y if xy ̸= yx. Let H be a finite non-abelian group such that ΓG ∼= ΓH.

b) If H is nilpotent, is it true that G is nilpotent?
Comment of 2009:
This is true if |H| = |G| (A. Abdollahi, S. Akbari, H. R. Maimani, J. Algebra, 298 (2006), 468–492).
Comments of 2023: This is true if |Z(H)| ⩾|Z(G)| (H. Shahverdi, J. Algebra, 642 (2024), 60–64), using the earlier result under the additional assumption that the centralizer of every non-central element in H is abelian (V. Grazian, C. Monetta, J. Algebra, 633 (2023), 389–402).

c) If H is solvable, is it true that G is solvable?
A. Abdollahi, S. Akbari, H. R. Maimani
